definitions.definition: a length of time in the life of a particular person or in the history of a particular country

examples.text: Which **period of history** would you most like to have lived in?
This textbook covers the post-war period.
The church dates from the Norman period.
We are currently studying the early medieval period.
Like Picasso, she too had a blue period.
Most teenagers go through a period of rebelling.
The picture was painted by Picasso during his blue period.
the late Victorian period
the period covered by the book
a dark period in the country's history

definitions.definition: a length of time which is a division of an era. A period is divided into epochs.

examples.text: the Jurassic period
Dinosaurs died out during the Cretaceous period.

definitions.definition: any of the parts that a day is divided into at a school, college, etc. for study

examples.text: ‘What do you have next period?’ ‘French.’
a **free/study period** *(= for private study)*
We've got French next period.
I have two free periods on Tuesday afternoons.

definitions.definition: the flow of blood each month from the body of a woman who is not pregnant

examples.text: period pains
monthly periods
When did you last **have a period**?
I was thirteen when I started my period.
I have my period and don't feel too great.
Missing a period is often one of the first signs that a woman is pregnant.

definitions.definition: the mark ( . ) used at the end of a sentence and in some abbreviations, for example e.g.

wordOrigin: late Middle English (denoting the time during which something, especially a disease, runs its course): from Old French periode, via Latin from Greek periodos ‘orbit, recurrence, course’, from peri- ‘around’ + hodos ‘way, course’. The sense ‘portion of time’ dates from the early 17th cent.
